title: Complete Cortical Deafness / Central Deafness following Bilateral CVAs
chief_complaint: Immediately following my seizure, I could not hear anything at all. Now, I can hear sounds and recognize familiar music, but I still struggle to understand words, especially if there is any background noise or if people speak quickly.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset of total deafness following a tonic-clonic seizure associated with a second CVA (17 months after first CVA).
problem_summary.course: Total deafness for 1-2 weeks; faint buzzing at 2 weeks; perception of loud noises at 1 month. Recognition of environmental sounds and familiar music returned around 4 months. Speech perception began returning at 5-7 months (aided by lipreading) and improved gradually over 2 years, though deficits in noise persist.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral central involvement; behavioral deficits worse in the left ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Transient dysnomia and dysgraphia (cleared in days); left arm and leg paresis (residual from first CVA); inability to recognize unfamiliar music.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe difficulty understanding speech in noise; reliance on speechreading; inability to appreciate new music.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Highly motivated; wife is a speech-language pathologist who assists with auditory training.

history.present_illness: Patient suffered second CVA. Became confused, collapsed, had tonic-clonic seizure. Post-seizure presented with total inability to hear.
history.otologic_history: No prior hearing loss reported. First CVA 17 months prior involved right temporal/parietal lobes.
history.medical_psych_history: History of two strokes in early 20s. Taken off Coumadin just before second stroke.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Essentially no response or responses in the profound loss range.

numeric_results.Thresholds: No response or Profound (>90 dB HL)

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present and normal bilaterally, indicating integrity of the lower brainstem and peripheral system.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Normal morphology and latencies bilaterally. Responses observed down to 30 dB nHL.

tests.name: Middle Latency Response (MLR)
tests.key_findings: Na, Pa, Nb, and Pb responses were absent. Large positive wave observed around 20 msec interpreted as myogenic artifact.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Hearing sensitivity improved to the severe-to-profound loss range bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Thresholds improved considerably, varying from normal levels to mild hearing loss bilaterally. Subjective hearing did not always correlate with audiogram fluctuations.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Detection Thresholds (SDT) consistent with pure tones. Spondee thresholds could not be established (no word understanding).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Spondee thresholds established at 10 months. Left ear consistently poorer than right.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: Background noise severely affects comprehension. Understanding drops to near zero with significant noise.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Word recognition (NU-6) showed right ear improvement over time, but left ear remained very poor. Binaural condition yielded best scores. Sentence recognition showed right ear reaching 100% by 2 years, while left ear fluctuated and remained poor.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Late auditory evoked potentials (N1, P2, P300) remained absent for either ear or binaurally, despite behavioral improvements.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Extensive Right Hemisphere damage (Temporal 64%, Parietal 45%, Frontal 40%, Insula 100%). Left Hemisphere damage limited but critical (Temporal 7% but 100% of Heschl's gyrus; Parietal 15%).

tests.name: Frequency Pattern Test (pediatric version)
tests.key_findings: Initial scores at 6 months were 30% for each ear. Right ear improved to 80% at 10 months, while left reached 47%. Scores fluctuated at 18 months (Right 60%, Left 30%) before reaching 100% bilaterally at >2 years.

overall_audiologic_summary: This is a case of complete cortical deafness evolving into central deafness/word deafness due to bilateral temporal lobe lesions (extensive right, focal left involving Heschl's gyrus). Peripheral hearing (OAEs/Reflexes/ABR) is intact. Pure tone thresholds recovered to near-normal, but profound deficits in speech processing persist, particularly in the left ear (contralateral to the massive right hemisphere lesion) and in noise. Electrophysiologic markers of cortical processing (MLR/LLR) remain absent, suggesting behavioral recovery is due to neural plasticity/reorganization not captured by standard electrode montages.
counseling_points: Explain the dissociation between 'hearing' (detection) and 'understanding' (processing); the ears are working, but the brain's auditory centers are damaged.
Emphasize the permanent difficulty with background noise; auditory processing in complex environments will remain compromised.
Highlight the importance of visual cues (speechreading) which the patient is already using effectively.
Discuss the 'better ear' phenomenon; the right ear is performing significantly better for speech than the left.
Encourage continued auditory training and exposure to familiar sounds/music to maximize plasticity, noting the patient's young age is a positive prognostic factor.
notes_for_actor: In the early scenes (acute), you are completely deaf. You cannot hear your own voice, so modulation might be difficult.
In later scenes, you can hear sounds clearly (doorbells, phone rings), but speech sounds like 'mumbling' or a foreign language.
If there is background noise in the scene, you should act confused and unable to follow the conversation.
You recognize old, familiar music (from before the stroke) but new music sounds like noise/nonsense to you.
You rely heavily on watching the speaker's face.
